import React from 'react'; import '../Duties.css'; import Navbar from './Navbar'; import Footer from './Footer'; export default function Duty11() { return ( <>

Fundamental Duty 11: Provide Education to Children

Article 51A(k) - Ensuring educational opportunities for young citizens

🧩 Comprehensive Understanding

Article 51A(k) establishes a parental obligation to:

  • Provide educational opportunities to children aged 6-14 years
  • Ensure regular school attendance and completion of elementary education
  • Create a conducive learning environment at home
  • Support the child's overall educational development

This duty complements the fundamental right to education under Article 21A and operates alongside:

  • Right of Children to Free and Compulsory Education Act, 2009 (RTE Act)
  • Various state education policies and programs

📖 Detailed Explanation

The constitutional and legal framework includes:

  • Legal Provisions:
    • Article 21A (Right to Education)
    • RTE Act's provisions for free and compulsory education
    • Prohibition of Child Labour (Amendment) Act, 2016
  • Implementation Mechanisms:
    • Sarva Shiksha Abhiyan (SSA) for universal elementary education
    • Mid-day Meal Scheme to improve attendance
    • School Management Committees with parent participation
  • Parental Responsibilities:
    • Ensuring admission in recognized schools
    • Monitoring academic progress
    • Providing necessary learning materials
    • Cooperating with school authorities

📜 Historical Context

This duty emerged from:

  • Constitutional Evolution:
    • 86th Amendment Act, 2002 inserted Article 51A(k)
    • Implemented along with Article 21A (Right to Education)
    • Came into force on April 1, 2010 with RTE Act
  • International Commitments:
    • UN Convention on Rights of the Child (1992)
    • Education For All (EFA) goals
    • UN Sustainable Development Goal 4 (Quality Education)
  • National Development Needs:
    • Addressing low literacy rates post-independence
    • Universalizing elementary education
    • Breaking intergenerational poverty cycles

🏛️ Judicial Interpretations

  • Unni Krishnan v. State of AP (1993) : Recognized education as implicit in right to life (Article 21). [AIR 1993 SC 2178]
  • Society for Unaided Private Schools v. Union of India (2012) : Upheld RTE Act's 25% reservation for disadvantaged groups. [(2012) 6 SCC 1]
  • Avinash Mehrotra v. Union of India (2009) : Recognized safety standards in schools as part of right to education. [(2009) 6 SCC 398]

🔍 Contemporary Challenges

  • Digital divide in online education
  • Quality disparities between government and private schools
  • Child labor preventing school attendance
  • Gender gap in certain regions
  • Implementation of inclusive education for children with disabilities
); }
